clinical_study.brief_title: The Bipolar Illness Onset Study (the BIO Study)
clinical_study.official_title: The Bipolar Illness Onset Study (the BIO Study)

lead_sponsor.agency: Mental Health Services in the Capital Region, Denmark

clinical_study.source: Mental Health Services in the Capital Region, Denmark

brief_summary.textblock: This longitudinal study aims to identify 1) a composite blood-based biomarker, 2) a composite electronic Smartphone-based biomarker and 3) a neurocognitive signature for bipolar disorder

detailed_description.textblock: The study will include 300 patients with newly diagnosed/first episode bipolar disorder, 200 healthy siblings or child family members and 100 healthy individuals without a family history of affective disorder. All individuals will be investigated with repeated blood tests, Smartphone recordings, neuropsychological tests and brain imaging during a five to ten year study period.

secondary_outcome.measure: Composite smartphone based biomarker including self reported and smartphone generated data
secondary_outcome.description: Composite smartphone based biomarker including 1) self reported data and 2) smartphone generated data on physical activity 3) social activity and 4) voice features collected during phone calls

secondary_outcome.measure: Composite neurocognitive marker including "Cold" and "Hot" cognition.
secondary_outcome.description: Composite neurocognitive marker including "Cold" cognition assessed with neuropsychological tests probing verbal memory and executive function and "Hot" cognition assessed with a comprehensive computerized battery of cognitive tests probing (i) emotional processing (ii) reward processing and (iii) emotional regulation.

arm_group.description: Patients with newly diagnosed bipolar disorder
Healthy first generation relatives to the included patients
Healthy individuals without a family history of psychiatric disorders

study_pop.textblock:
1. 300 patients referred to the Copenhagen Affective Disorder Clinic as newly diagnosed/first episode bipolar patients, i.e., onset of first manic or hypomanic episode or when the diagnosis of bipolar disorder is made for the first time.
2. 200 first-generation relatives (siblings and children aged 15 to 40 years) to the recruited newly diagnosed/first episode bipolar patients.
3. 100 age-, gender- and IQ-matched sample of healthy individuals without a first-generation family history of affective disorders recruited among blood donors from the Blood Bank at Rigshospitalet, Copenhagen, as in prior studies.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
1. Newly diagnosed/first episode bipolar patients,
2. First-generation relatives (siblings and children aged 15 to 40 years) to the recruited newly diagnosed/first episode bipolar patients.
3. Age- and gender matched sample of healthy individuals without a first-generation family history of effective disorders
Exclusion Criteria:
1. Significant physical disorders
2. Schizophrenia or related disorders
